FeedItems.Summary: We’re happy to announce that we released NuGet 1.7 today. This release includes several new features as well as over 75 bug fixes. Details are in the NuGet 1.7 Release Notes.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Latest fxcop fixes" (#6544) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "Status page message history should show most recent first" (#6379) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Right now the message history at the bottom of the status page goes from old to recent. It should go from recent to old.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Status page should show times in user local time" (#4865) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16807822/31746448-5544de3c-b41c-11e7-9eb9-1aa9015819c9.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "It should be possible to post a fallback message to the status page when the status backend was down" (#6549) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
We had a status backend downtime due to another service being down that was out of our control.

It should be possible to post a fallback message to the page manually when the backend is down.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Fix email verification issue for AAD/MSA registration" (#6548) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Fix issue https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6389

If the user registers using the MSA/AAD account, we will confirm the account and set up the email address automatically without sending any confirmation email. 

When the user changes email address, we will send the confirmation email as before.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Fix bugs - issue 6422" (#6512) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Fix bugs - issue 6422:  https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6422

The previous code will remove the credential firstly, which lead to empty  scopes for any kinds of credentials, so the message will always be "NonScopedApiKeyDescription". In order to fix that, we get the credential description firstly before removing operation, and use that description to determine the email content.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Can we define packageType = Template in a .csproj file?" (#7389) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi 👋 

I'm trying to see if it's possible to package a nuget from a `.csproj` where the package type is a `Template`.

---

NuGet product used: `VS UI` | `dotnet.exe`
dotnet.exe --version: `2.1.403`
VS version: `15.8.7`
OS version (i.e. win10 v1803 (17134.345)):

So I'm trying to [create a new custom template using the `dotnet new` template](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tutorials/create-custom-template). Part of the steps include creating a `.nupkg`. [The example documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tutorials/create-custom-template#pack-the-template-into-a-nuget-package) says to do this using `nuget pack <nuspec file>`.

I'm trying to do this with `dotnet pack` instead. `nuget.exe` isn't in my path (yes, I know I can download it, etc) so I'm trying to do with the existing tools possible / least amount of friction.

In the `.nuspec` file it says we need to define the nuget package to be a  `template` like:

```
<packageTypes>
  <packageType name="Template" />
</packageTypes>
```

Is there a way we can define this in a `.csproj` file, so then I might be able to use `dotnet pack` instead?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet self-embedded licenses and expressions pack" (#7355) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Related to #4628.

Building on top of https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Packaging-License-within-the-nupkg

Add the ability to pack self contained licenses and expressions. 

Details [here](https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/pull/1704). The link will be public soon. 

Related to https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7301

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Unsigned package from a repository that says `allPackagesSigned` should fail restore" (#7388) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
If a repository announces `All packages signed` the current code does not throw for unsigned packages in restore, even though validation failed.

This is an error case, thus it should fail restore.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Migrate packages.config to PackageReference unexpectedly closes Visual Studio " (#7387) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Environment
*   Visual Studio Community 2017 Preview 15.9.0 Preview 3.0
*   Side-by-side install with VS Community 2017
*   Windows 10 Professional 1803 (17134.345)

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem
Only VS Preview was opened, not regular VS.

1.   Open .NET Framework 4.6.1 Console Application with multiple NuGet packages installed. 
2.   Default package management format is set to `packages.config`
3.   Right-click on References, choose "Migrate packages.config..."
4.   Visual Studio shuts down with no error message.

## More Information
Setting the default package management format to PackageReference OR initializing NuGet by opening package manager allows the converter to run. The documentation "Know Issues" suggests doing this to display the context menu item, but I don't see sudden closing of VS mentioned.

The Windows Application Event Log does have several errors, which I've attached. Event Log Text, below (oldest to newest).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "C++ restore target doesn't restore when executed from command line " (#7386) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet product used msbuild /t:restore
VS version: 15.8.169+g1ccb72aefa
OS version: win10 v1803 (17134.286)):

Worked before? no

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create new **Windows Console Application** for **C++**
2. Add nuget package reference, i.e. for jmessage-cpp
3. Wait, packages.config will be created
4. Switch to console, remove packages folder from project
5. msbuild /t:restore,build ConsoleApplication1\ConsoleApplication1.vcxproj

## Verbose Logs

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Targeting net461, nuget doesn't use netstandard2.0 version of packages" (#7385) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):
2.1.402
VS version (if appropriate):
15.8.6

When adding a package reference with dependencies on .netstandard2.0, .netstandard1.6 and net451, nuget doesn't use .netstandard2.0 constraints.

1. Create a net sdk project targeting net461
2. Add PackageReference Microsoft.Diagnostics.EventFlow.Core 1.5.1
3. Add PackageReference Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions 2.1.1
4. dotnet restore

warning NU1608: Detected package version outside of dependency constraint: Microsoft.Diagnostics.EventFlow.Core 1.5.1 requires Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions (>= 1.1.1 && < 2.0.0) but version Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions 2.1.1 was resolved.

Microsoft.Diagnostics.EventFlow.Core as following dependencies
.NETFramework, Version=v4.7.1
Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions (>= 2.0.1)
.NETFramework, Version=v4.5.1
Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions (>= 1.1.1 && < 2.0.0)
.NETFramework, Version=v1.6
Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions (>= 1.1.1 && < 2.0.0)
.NETFramework, Version=v2.0
Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.Abstractions (>= 2.0.1)

As, net461 supports netstandard2.0, I expect it resolves with .NETFramework, Version=v2.0 constraints but it seems it use either net451 or netstandard1.6.

This command has been long announced as deprecated. 
It's time to actually do it. 

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/f9fa6b3ab4e485a4cac9e88215c59d0c4b0a8ba6/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.PowerShellCmdlets/Cmdlets/OpenPackagePageCommand.cs#L45

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet nuget push to local feeds should use v3 folder structure" (#7383) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: `dotnet nuget push MyPackage.1.0.0.nupkg -s ~/myFeed/` to an empty folder defaults to a v2 feed. It should default to a v3 feed, so on linux if I hand edit a `PackageReference` and get the case wrong, it can still find the package.

Events.RelatedBody:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Move Pack warning codes from 51xx to 55xx" (#7381) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Per https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/2450#discussion_r223834237, our pattern normally sohuld be X000-X499 are errors, while X500-X999 are warnings. 

Should we change this in pack retroactively? 
What do we do about new warnings?
4.9? 5.0?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Concurrent nuget install failures" (#7380) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We are using TeamCity with multiple agents on the same physical machine. We want to have all the agents share the same global packages folder to save disk space. Even then, it is not enough and we clear the packages from time to time. The result is that we have only one shared global packages folder, but install and restore operations fail regularly after we clear the locals caches.

We get errors like these
- `Access to the path 'bqipdjvv.1mg' is denied.`
- `The directory is not empty.`

Unfortunately, the NuGetScratch folder is located under the `%temp%` folder which TeamCity override per agent. What we understand is that the scratch folder is used to lock the downloads and installs of packages in the global cache. If we try to install the same package for the first time from different `nuget install` at the same time, the second will wait for the first one to finish without problem. 
However, if I repeat the experiment with different `%temp%` at least one of the `nuget install` will fail.

Is there any reason that the NuGetScratch folder is located in `%temp%` while other NuGet folders are in `%localappdata%` or the user folder?

Do you think there is a way to make this work anyway? I mean using nuget from different TeamCity agents sharing the same global packages folder but not the same `%temp%` folder?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack package does not have license information" (#7379) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Package https://www.nuget.org/packages/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack should include license information as other packages owned by the nuget account.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Block NuGet package" (#7378) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
After finally [recovering](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/17522) from the [System.Net.Http](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/23306) [package](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/25773) [hell](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/22781) we would like to block the package entirely.

I'm looking for a way to block the package from ever installing, so not blocking or locking a version but the entire package (due to a dependency or developer error). The block should be in the solution folder of the application so that every developer will have the block once updating from SVN.

I've looked at the NuGet.config and .nuspec documentation but was unable to find such a feature. My Google-fu also didn't yield any results. It seems that such an option [is not available](https://stackoverflow.com/posts/52715945) and would like to see this feature be added.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Disable package download plugins by default" (#7377) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Any package download plugging should be disabled by default.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org" (#30) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The spec to **Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org** , is ready for **review**:

|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|:----------|:------------------|
|[Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Show-source-repository-information-for-packages-on-nuget.org) | https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4941 |

**Note**: This is a short term feature to just light up the repository information on nuget.org using the `<repository>`  metadata in the nuspec. We plan to revisit the detailed functionality, in future.
